Article.Abstract: Respiratory challenge of H-2(b) mice with an H3N2 influenza A virus causes an acute, transient pneumonitis characterized by the massive infiltration of CD8(+) T lymphocytes. The inflammatory process monitored by quantitative analysis of lymphocyte populations recovered by bronchoalveolar lavage is greatly enhanced by prior exposure to an H1N1 virus, with the recall of cross-reactive CD8(+)-T-cell memory leading to more rapid clearance of the infection from the lungs. The predominant epitope recognized by the influenza virus-specific CD8(+) set has long been thought to be a nucleoprotein (NP(366-374)) presented by H-2D(b) (D(b)NP(366)). This continues to be true for the secondary H3N2-->H1N1 challenge but can no longer be considered the case for the primary response to either virus. Quantitative analysis based on intracellular staining for gamma interferon has shown that the polymerase 2 protein (PA(224-233)) provides a previously undetected epitope (D(b)PA(224)) that is at least as prominent as D(b)NP(366) during the first 10 days following primary exposure to either the H3N2 or H1N1 virus. The response to D(b)NP(366) seems to continue for longer, even when infectious virus can no longer be detected, but there is no obvious difference in the prevalence of memory T cells specific for D(b)NP(366) and D(b)PA(224). The generalization that the magnitude of the functional memory T-cell pool is a direct consequence of the clonal burst size during the primary response may no longer be useful. Previous CD8(+)-T-cell immunodominance heirarchies defined largely by cytotoxic T-lymphocyte assays may need to be revised.
Article.ArticleTitle: A previously unrecognized H-2D(b)-restricted peptide prominent in the primary influenza A virus-specific CD8(+) T-cell response is much less apparent following secondary challenge.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Immunology, St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, Memphis, Tennessee, USA.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were infected i.n. or i.p. with influenza A PR8 virus. BAL fluid cells, spleen cells and lymph node cells were collected. In a separate experiment, mice infected i.p. with 10^8.5 EID50 PR8 virus were given a secondary challenge i.n. with 1X10^6.8 EID50 influenza A HKx31 virus.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: BAL CD8+ T cells showed a stronger response than spleen cells and lymph node cells in intranasally-primed mice. Secondary challenge with HKx31 virus affected the dominance of the response but the epitope-specific response was still positive. IFN-g ELISPOT showed a similar result.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were infected with HKx31 influenza A virus and BAL fluid cells were collected. Spleen cells and lymph node cells were also tested.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Single alanine-substituted analogs of the epitope showed that residues N5 and Y9 were critical for T cell recognition. BAL CD8+ T cells showed a stronger response than spleen cells and lymph node cells. IFN-g ELISPOT showed a similar result.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were primed with the PR8 virus, secondarily infected with HKx31 virus, and fed BrdU in drinking water. Lymph node and spleen cells were then collected and stained with epitope-specific tetramer to access in vivo proliferation.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Epitope/Db tetramer-specific cells from PR8 virus-primed mice proliferated in response to secondary in vivo HKx31 influenza virus challenge as determined by BrdU incorporation assay. Lymph node and spleen T CD8+ cells showed similar responses.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were first infected i.p. with 10^8.5 EID50 PR8 virus and then given a secondary challenge i.n. with 10^6.8 EID50 influenza A HKx31 virus 42 days later.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: BAL, spleen, and lymph node CD8+ T cells were all positive.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were infected with HKx31 influenza A virus and splenocytes were restimulated in vitro with the epitope.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Single alanine-substituted analogs of the epitope showed that residues N5 and Y9 were critical for T cell recognition.
BAL and spleen CD8+ T cells were all positive.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were infected with HKx31 influenza A virus and splenocytes were restimulated in vitro with HKx31-infected syngeneic splenocytes.

Mice were infected i.n. or i.p. with influenza A PR8 virus. BAL fluid cells, spleen cells and lymph node cells were collected. In a separate experiment, mice infected i.p. with 10^8.5 EID50 PR8 virus were given a secondary challenge i.n. with 1X10^6.8 EID50 influenza A HKx31 virus.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: BAL CD8+ T cells showed a stronger response than spleen cells and lymph node cells. Secondary challenge with HKx31 virus affected the dominance of the response but the epitope-specific response was still positive. IFN-g ELISPOT showed a similar result.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were primed with the PR8 virus, secondary infected with HKx31 virus, and fed BrdU in drinking water. Lymph node and spleen cells were then collected and stained with epitope-specific tetramer to access in vivo proliferation.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Epitope/Db tetramer-specific cells from PR8 virus-primed mice proliferated in response to secondary in vivo HKx31 influenza virus challenge as determined by BrdU incorporation assay. Lymph node and spleen T CD8+ cells showed similar responses.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: BAL CD8+ T cells showed a stronger response than spleen cells and lymph node cells. IFN-g ELISPOT showed a similar result.
BAL and spleen CD8+ T cells were all positive.
